translation.en: My name is Fred Brathwaite.
Most of you may know me as Fab 5 Freddy,
that guy that used to host that rap show on MTV.
translation.ko: MTV에서 랩 방송을 진행한 그 남자 말이다

translation.en: -♪ Fab 5 Freddy ♪ -♪ Yo, yo, yo ♪
-[man] The number one show. -♪ Rap music ♪
-♪ Fab 5 Freddy ♪ -♪ Yo, yo ♪
[Brathwaite] I grew up in the Bed-Stuy section of Brooklyn, New York.
My godfather was jazz drummer Max Roach and best friends with my dad.
translation.ko: 대부인 재즈 드러머 맥스 로치는 아버지의 절친한 친구였다

translation.en: Our house was a happening scene.
Good music playing, my mom's great food on the stove,
translation.ko: 좋은 음악이 흘러나오고 어머니의 맛있는 요리가 있고

translation.en: and my dad's friends at the house on the regular,
having spirited intellectual conversation over quality cannabis.
translation.ko: 질 좋은 대마초를 피우며 지적 대화를 나누는 공간이었다

translation.en: Like my dad and his friends,
I'm a long-time cannabis connoisseur and an advocate.
More than half of America agrees with me.
translation.ko: "미국의 대마초 인기" 미국의 절반 이상이 나와 동의한다

translation.en: As cannabis goes mainstream, it's easy to forget the past:
nearly 100 years of prohibition
and millions of lives destroyed in a war on drugs.
translation.ko: 수백만의 인생을 망친 마약과의 전쟁 말이다 "1급 약물: 마리화나, 헤로인 LSD, GHB, MDMA, 엑스터시"

translation.en: As this trend of legalization spreads across the country,
translation.ko: 미국 전역에 합법화의 바람이 불고 있는 지금

translation.en: you have to ask, "Why was cannabis ever made illegal in the first place?"
translation.ko: 왜 애초에 대마초를 금지했는지 묻고 싶어진다 "36개 주 의료용 10개 주 기호용"

translation.en: And why is America only now accepting it?
translation.ko: 미국은 왜 이제 와서 대마초를 용인하는 것인가?

translation.en: My journey to answer this question starts right here,
translation.ko: 이 질문의 답을 찾기 위한 여정은 바로 이곳

translation.en: in my father's old record collection.
The history of cannabis in America has long been tied
translation.ko: 미국의 대마초 역사는 미국의 음악 역사와

translation.en: to the history of music in America.
Almost 100 years ago,
the biggest advocates of the day were jazz musicians.
translation.ko: 가장 열렬한 대마초 지지층은 바로 재즈 뮤지션들이었다

translation.en: [man] They used euphemisms.
translation.ko: 대체어를 사용했어요 "릴 그린 날 녹초로 만들 거야"

translation.en: Cab Calloway, of course, was one of the first
translation.ko: "패츠 월러 네가 독사라면" 캡 캘러웨이의 '리퍼 맨'이 그중 최초였죠

translation.en: with a song called "The Reefer Man."
translation.ko: 캡 캘러웨이의 '리퍼 맨'이 그중 최초였죠 "벅 워싱턴 꽁초는 남겨둬"

translation.en: 99.9% of the public wouldn't have no idea what he was talking about.
translation.ko: 그게 무슨 말인지는 대중의 99.9%가 몰랐을 거예요 "래리 랫소 슬로먼 '리퍼 매드니스' 저자"

translation.en: [Brathwaite] Reefer, gauge, jive, and weed
were some of the slang words jazz greats used
translation.ko: 유명한 재즈 뮤지션들은 대마초를 노래할 때

translation.en: when singing about cannabis.
These terms would become some of the popular slang still in use today.
translation.ko: 그때 사용됐던 단어들이 오늘날에도 널리 쓰이고 있다

translation.en: [man 2] Not only were jazz musicians smoking it,
but everybody knew that it gave them a leg up.
translation.ko: 확실히 이들의 창작에 도움이 됐죠 "스티브 헤이거, 작가 '하이 타임스' 전 편집장"

translation.en: When you got high on cannabis, the music slowed down a little bit.
And you could flow improvisationally.
translation.ko: 그러면 물 흐르듯 즉흥 연주를 할 수 있어요

translation.en: [man 3] The cat that smoked marijuana,
they had better know that... Fats Wallace and Duke Ellington and all of them.
translation.ko: 알 사람은 다 알죠 패츠 월러, 듀크 엘링턴 전부 다 했어요

translation.en: They help you be very creative.
I've been smoking for 70 years
and really enjoyed it.
Way back in the days in the jazz era, they were speaking on the plant
translation.ko: 그 옛날 재즈 시대 때 대마초를 노래했던 이유는

translation.en: because the plant was something that was a way of helping them find they groove
translation.ko: 뮤지션들이 느낌 잡는 도구로 대마초를 썼기 때문이죠 "스눕 독 힙합 전설, 대마초 사업가"

translation.en: and find they mind and find they mental, to create some of the most classic music
translation.ko: 지금껏 인간이 쓰고 부른 노래 중 손에 꼽는 명곡을 만들 수 있도록

translation.en: that was ever written, that was ever produced,
translation.ko: 정신 상태를 다지는 데에 도움이 된 거예요

translation.en: that was ever sung, and it's timeless.
There's something about that cannabis that brings the best out of whoever you are,
translation.ko: 왠진 몰라도 대마초를 피우면 최고의 모습을 꺼낼 수 있게 돼요

translation.en: if you tap into your spirit or why it's here.
[man 3] There's a lot of reefer songs going around. "Light Up."
translation.ko: "리로이 스미스 자이브를 든 남자" 리퍼 노래가 참 많죠 "버스터 베일리 불 피워"

translation.en: [hums melodically] ♪ Light up ♪
There's another one.
♪ All the jive is gone ♪
♪ All the jive is gone ♪
♪ I had some fun, but now I'm on the run Because all the jive is gone ♪
translation.ko: 그동안 즐거웠지만 이젠 달려야 해 자이브가 다 떨어졌으니까

translation.en: Because back in the day, they called marijuana jive.
♪ The latest crave The country's rave is jive, jive, jive ♪
translation.ko: 요즘 사람들이 미친 듯 원하는 건 자이브...

translation.en: [Brathwaite] You can trace the roots of cannabis to the city of New Orleans,
translation.ko: 대마초의 뿌리는 뉴올리언스에서 확인할 수 있다

translation.en: a port city that was a melting pot of cultures and the birthplace of jazz.
translation.ko: 온갖 문화가 섞인 항구도시로 재즈가 탄생한 곳이기도 하다

translation.en: That's right, baby, New Orleans.
At a time when only the hippest cats knew where to find some good reefer
translation.ko: 그때는 오직 멋진 친구들만 어떤 언더그라운드 클럽에

translation.en: in those underground clubs.
[man] Here's the original reefer song.
♪ Hide the reefer Here comes the creeper ♪
♪ Hide the reefer Here comes the creeper ♪
♪ Hide the reefer Here comes the creeper ♪
♪ Hide the reefer Here comes the creeper ♪
[Brathwaite] Cannabis and its close cousin hemp
translation.ko: 대마초와 그 사촌뻘인 삼은 아시아에서 수백 년 사용됐고

translation.en: were used for centuries throughout Asia
translation.ko: 대마초와 그 사촌뻘인 삼은 아시아에서 수백 년 사용됐고 "미국 대마초의 기원 1900년대 아시아"

translation.en: and traveled across the globe along trade routes.
[Sloman] Marijuana doesn't actually become a social problem per se,
translation.ko: "1910년, 텍사스 엘패소 루이지애나 뉴올리언스" 초기에 마리화나는 사회 문제로 여겨지지 않았어요

translation.en: until there's early reports in El Paso Texas and also in New Orleans
translation.ko: 그러다가 엘패소와 뉴올리언스에서 마리화나를 피우는 소수자들이

translation.en: of minorities smoking marijuana.
Marijuana, from its entry point into the US, has been associated with two groups
translation.ko: 마리화나는 미국에 들어올 때부터 그때나 지금이나 미국인들에게

translation.en: that give Americans great amounts of trepidation,
translation.ko: 큰 불안을 주는 두 집단과 "배즈 드레싱어, 작가 존 제이 범죄 대학 교수"

translation.en: historically then and even now.
And that's African-Americans and jazz culture in New Orleans and Mexicans.
translation.ko: 재즈 문화를 이끈 뉴올리언스 흑인 그리고 멕시코인들이죠

translation.en: In fact, the name cannabis was shifted in the mainstream discourse to marijuana,
translation.ko: "대마초 널리 쓰이는 약용 식물" 실제로 '칸나비스'라는 이름이 주류에 의해 '마리화나'로 변한 건

translation.en: in order to make the association with Mexican-ness.
translation.ko: 멕시코와의 연관성을 만들려고 그런 거예요 "마리화나 위험하고 중독적인 외국 마약"

translation.en: We're talking about this happening in the first three decades of the 20th Century,
translation.ko: 지금 하는 얘기는 20세기 초 약 30년 동안 일어난 일이에요

translation.en: which are some of the most xenophobic decades in American history,
translation.ko: 미국 역사 중 외국인 혐오가 가장 심했던 때라고 할 수 있죠

translation.en: although we're doing pretty well with that now.
But, you know, really intensely xenophobic moments.
translation.ko: 그때는 외국인 혐오 정서가 극에 달했던 시대예요

translation.en: So you're talking about individuals coming in through Mexico into Texas,
translation.ko: 멕시코 사람들이 텍사스를 통해 미국에 들어오고

translation.en: the coming of Jews and Italians,
the great migration of African-Americans into northern cities.
translation.ko: 미국 흑인들이 대대적으로 북부로 이동했던 시기인 거죠

translation.en: So the whole population of urban America is shifting,
translation.ko: 도시화된 미국의 거의 모든 인구가 이동하면서

translation.en: and there's a ton of anxiety around this population.
translation.ko: 이주해온 이들에 대한 불안감이 심했던 거죠

translation.en: They were worried that the blacks in New Orleans
who were smoking marijuana
would then use it to seduce white teenagers
translation.ko: 백인 청소년들을 유혹하고 전혀 알려진 바 없었던

translation.en: and get them hooked on this mysterious drug that they knew nothing about.
translation.ko: 신비한 마약에 빠져들게 할까 봐 걱정이 됐던 거예요

translation.en: Jazz was the new music of the 20th century.
translation.ko: 20세기의 새로운 음악이 재즈였죠 "필 솁 링컨 센터 재즈 큐레이터"

translation.en: And Louis Armstrong is its progenitor.
Louis Armstrong is the most important seminal figure in the development of jazz.
translation.ko: 루이 암스트롱은 재즈의 발전에 가장 중요한 역할을 한 사람이에요

translation.en: I was born, you know, in 1900. In James Alley, they called it.
It's the back of town. That's the real New Orleans.
And as a little boy, they used to call me little Louis.
translation.ko: 어렸을 때는 다들 저를 꼬맹이 루이라고 불렀어요

translation.en: And I grew up there listening to all the good music.
[Hager] We know that Louis started smoking weed early on.
translation.ko: 루이가 일찍이 대마초를 피운 건 다들 아는 사실이에요

translation.en: And he smoked it every day of his life.
translation.ko: 평생 하루도 안 빠지고 피운 셈이죠

translation.en: [Sloman] Louis was one of our glorious, early potheads.
And obviously, if you listen to his music, you can see that pot,
if anything, had a very salutary effect on his music.
[Brathwaite] By the 1920s, some states had begun outlawing marijuana usage,
translation.ko: 1920년대가 되자 일부 주에서 마리화나 사용을 금했다

translation.en: including California.
In 1930, Louis Armstrong was playing a gig at the Cotton Club in Culver City,
when he got arrested for smoking a joint outside during a set break.
translation.ko: 휴식 시간에 밖에 나가서 대마초를 피운 죄로 체포됐다

translation.en: [Sloman] We're in Louis Armstrong's house, which has been preserved as a museum.
translation.ko: 이곳은 루이 암스트롱의 집이에요 박물관으로 보존되어 있죠 "루이 암스트롱 집 국가 역사 기념물"

translation.en: This whole desk is Louis' tape recorder, Louis' glasses maybe, I don't know.
translation.ko: 여기에 루이의 녹음기도 있고 이건 루이의 안경일 수 있겠네요

translation.en: All the tapes.
[Brathwaite] Most of what we know about Louis Armstrong,
translation.ko: 루이 암스트롱에 대해 알고 싶은 건

translation.en: we know from his own words and letters.
translation.ko: 루이가 직접 한 말과 쓴 글을 통해 알 수 있다

translation.en: He was very open about his cannabis use.
And he did not mince words in his opposition to prohibition.
translation.ko: 대마초 금지에 반대하는 자신의 의견도 감추지 않았다

translation.en: [Sloman] One of the things Louis never understood was why marijuana was illegal.
translation.ko: 루이는 마리화나가 왜 불법인지 평생 이해하지 못했어요

translation.en: He told his manager,
"I'm not so particular about having a permit to carry a gun.
translation.ko: '총 소지에 면허가 필요한 건 이해할 수 있어'

translation.en: All I want is a permit to carry that good shit.
translation.ko: '나도 좋은 물건을 피울 수 있는 면허를 갖고 싶다고'

translation.en: You must see to it that I have special permission
to smoke all the reefers that I want to when I want,
translation.ko: '대마초를 피울 수 있게 특별 면허증을 받아줘'

translation.en: or I will just have to put this horn down."
He was way ahead of his time because Louis wanted to get a permit for marijuana.
translation.ko: 마리화나 면허를 원했던 걸 보니 루이는 시대를 앞서갔네요

translation.en: "I can't afford to be tense, fearing that any minute I'm going to be arrested,
translation.ko: '갑자기 체포될지도 모른다는 공포와 긴장에 빠져 살 수는 없어'

translation.en: brought to jail, for a silly little minor thing like marijuana."
translation.ko: '마리화나처럼 사소한 것 때문에 감옥에 가야 한다니'

translation.en: [Brathwaite] Louis' words were sensible, yet radical for that time.
translation.ko: 루이의 생각은 합리적이었지만 그 시대에 맞지 않았다

translation.en: And they still ring true today.
translation.ko: 그의 말은 지금도 맞는 말처럼 들린다

translation.en: How is it that a mild intoxicant, a plant that grows naturally all over the world,
translation.ko: 미국 정부는 세계 곳곳에 나며 약한 중독성을 띠는 이 식물을

translation.en: could be so feared by the American government
and become worthy of a war?
Huh. It all comes down to one man.
His name? Harry Anslinger.
[man] Our distinguished guest for this evening is Harry J. Anslinger,
translation.ko: 오늘 밤 참석해준 손님은 해리 J 앤슬링어 씨

translation.en: United States Commissioner of Narcotics, Treasury Department.
[Anslinger] It is the duty of the Treasury Department
to damn the harmful and malignant stream of narcotic drugs.
The Treasury Department intends to pursue a relentless warfare
against the despicable, dope-peddling vulture
who preys on the weakness of his fellow man.
One of the biggest architects of marijuana prohibition,
maybe even the father of marijuana prohibition,
translation.ko: "카산드라 프레더릭 마약 정책 동맹 뉴욕 지부장" 금지화의 아버지가 바로 해리 앤슬링어예요

translation.en: is Harry Anslinger.
[Sloman] Harry Anslinger was an associate in the Prohibition department.
translation.ko: 해리 앤슬링어는 원래 금주국 소속 직원이었는데

translation.en: In 1930, he becomes the first head of the Bureau of Narcotics.
What you have to realize though about Anslinger is that...
translation.ko: 이 앤슬링어에 대해 알고 계셔야 할 것은

translation.en: deep in his bones, he was a racist.
And that informed a lot of the way he viewed,
translation.ko: 그 점을 염두에 두면 무해한 식물을 피우는

translation.en: you know, what measures should be taken against people
translation.ko: 사람들을 처리하는 데 있어서 어떤 견해를 가졌는지

translation.en: who were basically smoking a very innocent flower. [chuckles]
Uh, I might say that, uh, we find this teenage addiction
translation.ko: 우리가 마주한 청소년의 중독 문제는 "해리 앤슬링어 1952년"

translation.en: in certain segments and certain neighborhoods.
translation.ko: 특정 지역과 특정 동네에서 일어나고 있습니다

translation.en: For instance, you can almost chalk it down this way.
translation.ko: 예를 들자면 이렇게 간략히 정리할 수 있어요

translation.en: You see very little of it in New England.
You come to New York, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh...
Detroit, Chicago, New Orleans.
[Brathwaite] Most of America at that time
would've known exactly what Anslinger meant right here.
translation.ko: 무엇을 의미하는지는 국민 대부분이 알았을 것이다

translation.en: These cities were known to have high populations of black and brown people.
translation.ko: 그가 언급한 도시는 유색인 인구수가 많은 도시였다

translation.en: Anslinger was a master at PR and at fake news.
So what he was able to do was always create the other.
translation.ko: 그래서 항상 한 게 적대시할 대상을 만드는 거였죠

translation.en: He had been always amassing these horrid, lurid stories
translation.ko: 항상 마리화나가 초래한 끔찍하고 충격적인 이야기를 잔뜩 쌓아두고 다녔어요

translation.en: of the devastation that's wrought by marijuana.
translation.ko: 끔찍하고 충격적인 이야기를 잔뜩 쌓아두고 다녔어요

translation.en: So this is just a small sample of what I call The Gore File.
"Hampton Negro Conference."
"Marijuana created a magnificent dream scenery and insanity."
Okay, here's a good one.
"Kills six in a hospital, Mexican crazed by marijuana
runs amok with a butcher knife."
And this was published in the New York Times in 1925.
This is a good one.
"Mexican family go insane.
A woman and her four children have been driven insane
translation.ko: '마리화나를 먹은 한 여성과 네 명의 아이들이'

translation.en: by eating the marijuana plant, according to doctors
who say there is no hope of saving the children's lives.
translation.ko: '정신이상 상태에 빠졌다 의사의 말에 따르면' '아이들의 목숨은 구할 수 없고'

translation.en: And that the mother will be insane for the rest of her life."
At that time, most Americans knew nothing about marijuana.
translation.ko: 그때 미국인들은 대마초에 대해 아는 게 없었죠

translation.en: So, um, the idea was, at least for Anslinger,
was to build up this consciousness of this public menace,
translation.ko: 대마초가 공공의 적이라는 정서를 심는 것이었어요

translation.en: which really, you know, was not a public menace at all.
And one of the great cases is the Victor Licata case.
translation.ko: 유명한 사건이 있어요 빅터 리카타 사건이죠

translation.en: And this is a kind of place where Anslinger would... um...
This is Inside Detective magazine.
And this is the Marijuana Maniac.
One day, Victor Licata takes an ax and murders his father, mother,
translation.ko: 빅터는 도끼로 아버지, 어머니 그리고 형제 셋을 죽였어요

translation.en: two brothers and a sister.
translation.ko: "도끼 든 사나이 4명 살해 미친 청소년이 가족을 죽이다"

translation.en: Immediately it gets linked to marijuana.
translation.ko: 사건은 곧바로 마리화나와 얽히죠 "정신이상을 일으키는 멕시코 마약 마리화나를 흡연"

translation.en: Actually, Victor Licata was a schizophrenic.
There was no evidence, of course, that marijuana caused any of this.
translation.ko: 마리화나가 원인이라는 증거는 아무 데도 없었죠

translation.en: But Anslinger, for years,
used these stories to promote the idea that weed just makes you totally insane.
translation.ko: 이런 이야기들로 대마초가 사람을 미치게 한다는 소문을 퍼뜨렸어요 "공포 파일 마리화나, 광기, 살인"

translation.en: [Brathwaite] Under Anslinger's leadership,
marijuana propaganda sprouted up everywhere.
Millions of Americans would read it, see it on newsreels in theaters,
translation.ko: 수백만 미국인이 신문으로 읽거나 영화가 시작되기 전에 나오는

translation.en: before feature films.
Marijuana, a Mexican weed smoked in cigarette form, called reefers.
translation.ko: 마리화나는 담배처럼 피우는 멕시코 마약으로 '리퍼'라고 하죠

translation.en: A one-way ticket to the nut house.
Should you ever be confronted with a temptation of taking that first puff
translation.ko: 혹시라도 대마초 담배를 한 입 피우고 싶은

translation.en: of a marijuana cigarette, don't do it. Don't do it. Don't do it.
[Brathwaite] And, eventually, there was a series of films, like Reefer Madness,
translation.ko: 곧 영화도 여러 편 나왔다 '리퍼 매드니스'는

translation.en: devoted entirely to creating misinformation and mass hysteria
translation.ko: 대마초에 대해 잘못된 정보를 전달하고 "청춘 암살자"

translation.en: around the plant.
[man] People say cannabis was causing folks to act crazy and behave aggressively.
translation.ko: 대마초 때문에 정신이 이상해지고 행동이 거칠어진다고 했어요

translation.en: It was causing these young pretty white girls to be lured away from their homes
translation.ko: 예쁘고 어린 백인 여자애들이 대마초 때문에 집을 뛰쳐나가서

translation.en: to become prostitutes.
And the federal government had to do something.
translation.ko: 정부에서 손을 써야 했어요 "칼 하트 박사"

translation.en: So, as a result, in 1937 cannabis was, in effect,
banned in the United States.
About this same time,
Mayor LaGuardia of New York City
commissioned a comprehensive report to be done on cannabis.
translation.ko: 대마초에 관한 종합 보고서 작성을 의뢰했죠

translation.en: [Sloman] The Marihuana Report from LaGuardia
devastated every tenet of Anslinger's philosophy
and said none of this is true.
There's nothing wrong with smoking pot.
That doesn't lead to criminality.
That it doesn't lead to addiction.
You know, all these bug-a-boos were completely not true.
translation.ko: 그때까지 알려진 소문들이 다 거짓이었던 거예요

translation.en: [Brathwaite] In the pages of the LaGuardia Report,
translation.ko: "치료 목적으로 활용 가능" 80년 전에 작성된 라과디아 보고서에서 과학자들은

translation.en: you can see that 80 years ago,
scientists had confirmed that cannabis was not at all
the evil Anslinger made it out to be.
[man] Back then, you didn't have internet. You didn't have access to information
the way you do so that you can unveil the bullshit.
translation.ko: 지금보다 떨어졌으니 거짓말을 밝혀낼 수가 없었죠

translation.en: It's sort of like being in school and them feeding you history.
translation.ko: 학교에서 가짜 역사를 주입받는 거랑 비슷해요 "비 리얼, 힙합 아티스트 대마초 사업가"

translation.en: They're going to feed you the history that they want to feed you.
translation.ko: 우리가 배웠으면 하는 것들만 골라서 들려주지

translation.en: They're not going to feed you the whole history.
Psychiatrists and sociologists, from 1936 on,
knew that there was nothing wrong with this weed
translation.ko: 대마초에 아무 문제가 없다는 걸 알고 있었어요

translation.en: and that it's much worse if you're drinking alcohol
translation.ko: 대마초 살짝 피우는 것보다 알코올이 안 좋다는 것도

translation.en: than if you're smoking a little reefer.
Our decision-makers chose at every juncture to ignore the science.
translation.ko: 국가의 의사 결정자들이 모든 부분에서 과학을 무시했어요

translation.en: To ignore the research.
At every moment when government officials could lead,
translation.ko: 정부 관료들이 앞장설 수 있을 때마다

translation.en: could actually use science, they chose propaganda.
translation.ko: 과학을 활용할 수 있을 때마다 선전을 택한 거예요

translation.en: They chose racism.
[Brathwaite] LaGuardia's report also uncovered that after the Marijuana Tax Act was passed,
translation.ko: 라과디아 보고서에서는 마리화나 세법 통과 이후

translation.en: people of color made up 78% of all marijuana arrests in New York City alone.
translation.ko: 마리화나로 체포된 뉴욕 시민 중 78%가 유색인인 것도 밝혔다

translation.en: This racial disparity would continue till today.
[Hager] Anslinger knew that his job wasn't really about trying to prevent people from getting high.
translation.ko: 앤슬링어는 국민들을 중독으로부터 지키려는 게 아니었어요

translation.en: It was trying to prevent people from going to jazz clubs
translation.ko: 재즈 클럽에 가서 다른 인종들과 춤추려는 사람들을

translation.en: and dancing with people from other races.
[Sloman] A lot of the music scene and the ancillary use of pot
translation.ko: 음악 업계에서 대마초를 기호용으로 사용하는 일은

translation.en: happened in New York.
And it happened in Harlem.
White kids, who were kind of hip kids, who were living in Brooklyn and in Queens,
translation.ko: 브루클린과 퀸스에 사는 잘나가는 백인 아이들이

translation.en: went up to Harlem on Saturday nights.
You know, there was integration.
I mean, you know, don't forget, racism was endemic then.
When they went up to Harlem, it was the first exposure that white people had
translation.ko: 그때 할렘에 간 백인 친구들이 백인 중에선 최초로

translation.en: to black culture.
[man] Jazz in its day, was treated as hip hop.
Marijuana was made illegal partially because of the jazz scene.
translation.ko: 마리화나의 불법화 배경에는 재즈 음악이 있었죠

translation.en: Because the jazz scene put black people and white people together,
translation.ko: 왜냐면 재즈로 인해 흑인 남성과 백인 여성이 어울렸거든요

translation.en: in particular black men and white women.
It was used as a tool of propaganda to say
marijuana not only makes these niggas uppity and think they're as smart as us,
translation.ko: 마리화나 때문에 흑인들은 자신이 백인만큼 똑똑한 줄 알고

translation.en: it allows our women to let their guard down and start to dance,
translation.ko: 백인 여성들은 흑인 남성에 대한 경계를 풀고

translation.en: have fun, have sex, fuck, procreate.
It relates to a lot of the cultural anxieties
that existed at the time, around the notion that too much of this music,
translation.ko: 문화적 불안감과 연결돼 있어요 마리화나와 재즈는 연결돼 있는데

translation.en: which is also associated with too much of those drugs,
translation.ko: 그런 재즈를 접하기 쉽게 내버려 둔다면

translation.en: is going to blacken the American population and American culture
translation.ko: 흑인들이 미국인과 미국 문화를 물들여서 끔찍한 결과를 가져올 거라고 본 거죠

translation.en: in all kinds of scary ways.
translation.ko: 끔찍한 결과를 가져올 거라고 본 거죠

translation.en: [man] Cannabis was always in Harlem
and we had various names for it. Like bou, as in bouquet.
translation.ko: 이름도 다양했죠 부케에서 딴 '부'라든가 "조지 넬슨 프레스턴 박사 아티스트, 학자"

translation.en: Um... weed, which people still use, you know, today.
Pot, yeah. Pot was, uh, one of the phrases.
Old school people call it reefer.
Bud, Mary Jane.
Grass, pot.
Sess, Buddha bless.
-Dank. -Hemp. Herb.
They used to call it Christmas Tree in Arizona.
Weed, marijuana.
[Brathwaite] The Harlem jazz scene spread across the country and around the world.
translation.ko: 할렘의 재즈 문화는 미국과 세계로 뻗어 나갔고

translation.en: And the music continued to grow in popularity.
Soon, black jazz musicians became household names.
translation.ko: 머지않아 흑인 재즈 뮤지션은 유명인이 되었다

translation.en: With the ever-present specter of integration,
translation.ko: 사라지지 않고 인종 대통합을 괴롭히는 유령답게

translation.en: Anslinger's team targeted the black community harder than ever.
translation.ko: 앤슬링어와 친구들은 흑인 사회에 유례없는 공격을 시작했다

translation.en: [Sloman] The Bureau of Narcotics had a so-called scientist named Dr. Munch.
translation.ko: 마약국에는 먼치 박사라고 하는 과학자가 있었어요

translation.en: He said that jazz musicians, when they smoke pot,
translation.ko: 그 사람은 재즈 뮤지션들이 대마초를 피우면

translation.en: time would kind of bend for them.
He says, one of the dangers of cannabis is that it slows time down.
translation.ko: 대마초가 위험한 이유 중 하나가 시간을 느리게 만든다는 거였어요

translation.en: And that's a bad thing.
You know, everybody's got to be on the same... four-four.
translation.ko: 모든 사람이 똑같이 4/4 박자여야 한다는 거죠

translation.en: They didn't-- They really, uh... They thought that was a sign of something evil.
translation.ko: 그것 때문에 대마초가 나쁘다고 진심으로 생각했나 봐요

translation.en: And they... just went after all the jazz people.
translation.ko: 그렇게 그냥 재즈 뮤지션들을 사냥하기 시작했죠

translation.en: The crackdown on jazz musicians is accelerated.
They were on Billie Holiday's case. Monk's case. Charlie Parker's case.
translation.ko: 빌리 홀리데이도 조사하고 멍크, 찰리 파커도 조사했어요

translation.en: [Sloman] People like Louis Armstrong, Cab Calloway, Duke Ellington,
translation.ko: 루이 암스트롱 캡 캘러웨이, 듀크 엘링턴

translation.en: Count Basie, Dizzy.
[man] Hey, cats, it's four o'clock in the morning.
Here we are in Harlem.
Everybody is here but the police, and they'll be here any minute.
translation.ko: 경찰 빼고 이미 다 왔어 경찰도 곧 올 테지

translation.en: It's high time, so catch this song. Here it is.
translation.ko: 지금이 딱 좋을 때니까 이 노래를 잘 들어

translation.en: [Brathwaite] Cannabis prohibition prompted Fats Waller to record this classic.
translation.ko: 대마초 불법화 덕분에 패츠 월러는 이 명곡을 썼다

translation.en: [Brathwaite] But he changed the lyrics just a little,
to pay homage to the biggest cannabis dealer of the day, Mezz Mezzrow.
translation.ko: 당시 최고의 대마초 업자였던 메즈 메즈로에게 경의를 표했다

translation.en: [Sloman] Mezz Mezzrow was a white Jewish guy from Chicago.
translation.ko: 메즈 메즈로는 시카고 출신의 유대계 백인이었어요

translation.en: [Dreisinger] He was the original, what Norman Mailer would come to call The White Negro
translation.ko: 노먼 메일러가 말한 '하얀 흑인'의 대표 주자였어요

translation.en: who imagined himself as kind of becoming black through music.
[Sloman] He was called the ambassador between the races.
He was called the white mayor of Harlem.
And he becomes the leading dealer to all the musicians in New York.
translation.ko: 뉴욕의 모든 뮤지션들을 상대하는 최고의 딜러로 성장했어요

translation.en: And the brand that he was selling was called the Mighty Mezz.
translation.ko: 그 사람이 판매한 브랜드가 바로 '마이티 메즈'였죠

translation.en: He had a big tree where he would stay under the tree.
translation.ko: 커다란 나무를 갖고 있었는데 그 아래에서 시간을 보냈죠

translation.en: And everybody knew that's where you got the Mighty Mezz.
translation.ko: 다들 마이티 메즈가 거기서 나온다는 걸 알았어요

translation.en: [Schaap] He became one of the leading marijuana dealers in Harlem.
translation.ko: 메즈는 할렘을 대표하는 마리화나 딜러가 되었어요

translation.en: So that there was a period where marijuana and all kinds of slang terms about it
translation.ko: 그래서 한때는 마리화나나 대마초를 나타내는 온갖 이름 대신

translation.en: used Mezzrow's name as a roller with a long joint.
translation.ko: 길게 말린 담배를 부를 때 메즈의 이름으로 불렀죠

translation.en: And Louis Armstrong loved him and he loved his high-quality marijuana.
translation.ko: 루이 암스트롱은 메즈를 좋아했고 메즈의 고품질 대마를 좋아했어요

translation.en: Mezz Mezzrow was arrested under the Prohibition of Marijuana Act.
translation.ko: 메즈로는 마리화나 금지법 때문에 체포된 적도 있어요

translation.en: And he's in jail for a day
translation.ko: "대마초로 유죄 선고 받은 뮤지션" 그렇게 하룻밤을 감옥에서 보냈는데

translation.en: and writes a note to the warden,
he's been misclassified as a white person.
translation.ko: 자신이 백인으로 수감됐는데 잘못된 것 같다고요

translation.en: [Dreisinger] When he was locked up on Riker's Island,
he actually insisted on being in the colored section.
translation.ko: 메즈는 자신을 유색인 감방에 넣어달라고 요청했어요

translation.en: Pretty fascinating figure. He was also--
Mezz Mezzrow was also a great influence on the Beats, Jack Kerouac,
translation.ko: 메즈로는 비트 세대에도 큰 영향을 미쳤어요 잭 케루악을 비롯해 비트 운동의 전임자 역을

translation.en: and he was a predecessor to that whole movement,
translation.ko: 잭 케루악을 비롯해 비트 운동의 전임자 역을

translation.en: the Beat Movement,
and taught them how to sort of be hip, be cool,
by way of influence of all things black.
[Brathwaite] The beatniks took the ethos of jazz
translation.ko: 비트족은 재즈의 기풍을 시와 문학 속에 녹여냈다

translation.en: and brought it into poetry and literature.
translation.ko: 비트족은 재즈의 기풍을 시와 문학 속에 녹여냈다 "울부짖음 - 앨런 긴즈버그 블루스 사람들 - 리로이 존스"

translation.en: You learn everything you can accrue, then come out and use it against them.
translation.ko: '쌓을 수 있는 만큼 배워서 밖에 나와 써먹어야 한다'

translation.en: [Preston] The immediacy of jazz, the immediacy of beat life,
brings together the cultural dynamic that opens up creative expression
translation.ko: 문화적 역학을 가능케 함으로써 다음 50, 60년 동안

translation.en: for the next 50, 60 years or so.
-Do you want to come upstairs? -[man] Let's do it.
Okay.
[Preston] One of the main characteristics of beat life was altered consciousness,
translation.ko: 비트 세대의 주요 특징은 의식 장애였어요

translation.en: how could altered consciousness contribute to art.
translation.ko: 의식 장애가 예술에 기여할 수 있다고 믿었죠

translation.en: I mean, asking a beat person if you smoked grass
was like asking them if they were alive.
We all got together the way people get together to have a drink.
translation.ko: 사람들이 모여서 술을 마시듯 우리도 같이 모였어요

translation.en: We would get together at each other's studios.
Somebody would take out a joint,
and we'd have a buzz.
I'm 79, and I've been smoking since I was 19.
So, what's that, 60 years?
It's probably hard to see me in this one,
but this is me in the artist's studio here.
translation.ko: 아티스트의 작업실에 방문한 제가 여기 있어요

translation.en: People today do not understand
what beat culture did for the freedom of expression.
translation.ko: 비트 문화가 표현의 자유에 무슨 역할을 했는지 몰라요

translation.en: Here's Ginsberg. We had this reading with City College
and the authorities were afraid that they were going to use profanity on campus.
translation.ko: 캠퍼스에서 욕설을 쓸까 봐 관계자들이 불안해했어요

translation.en: [Preston] You can tell by the way I talk,
that I must've smoked a hell of a lot of marijuana.
translation.ko: 얼마나 많은 마리화나를 피웠는지 예상할 수 있을 거예요

translation.en: Because everything I've said can be looked at
as being totally induced by reefer madness.
translation.ko: 모두 리퍼의 광기가 끌어냈다고 봐도 무방하거든요

translation.en: [Brathwaite] Influenced by the beatniks,
the hippie movement would bring cannabis into the mainstream consciousness
translation.ko: 히피 운동은 대중 의식 속으로 대마초를 가져올 수 있었다

translation.en: from cities to suburbs,
becoming a permanent part of the counterculture in America and beyond.
translation.ko: 대마초는 전 세계적으로 반문화의 필수 요소가 되었다

translation.en: [Preston] Hippie culture made it possible for marijuana to become legal...
translation.ko: 히피 문화 덕분에 마리화나는 합법화될 수 있었어요

translation.en: because so many people, meaning white people, smoked marijuana.
translation.ko: 왜냐면 수많은 백인들이 마리화나를 피우기 시작했거든요

translation.en: [Brathwaite] Cannabis was embraced by a new generation.
People smoked it in public.
White musicians now sang about it.
translation.ko: 백인 뮤지션들도 대마초를 노래에 담아 불렀다

translation.en: And the argument for legalization entered the national debate.
translation.ko: 그리하여 대마초 합법화가 전국적 논란거리가 되었다

translation.en: [Hager] Ginsberg is the one who really blows it up,
translation.ko: 이 문제에 불을 붙인 건 긴즈버그예요

translation.en: so that it becomes more than just a subcultural phenomenon,
translation.ko: "비트 시인 대마초 운동가" 덕분에 한낱 하위문화의 현상으로 남지 않게 되었죠

translation.en: because Ginsberg then began to kind of agitate for the legalization of marijuana.
translation.ko: "대마초는 재미있다" 그 후로 긴즈버그는 마리화나 합법화를 주장했거든요

translation.en: [Preston] Let me read you something that Allen wrote in 1965,
"No one has yet remarked that the suppression of Negro rights,
translation.ko: '지금까지 미국에서 흑인 권리, 문화, 감성의 탄압이'

translation.en: culture and sensibility in America,
has been complicated by the marijuana laws.
Use of marijuana has always been widespread
among the Negro population in this country.
And suppression of its use,
with constant friction and bludgeoning of the law,
has been a major unconscious or unmentionable method of assault
translation.ko: '무의식적이고 입에 담기 민망한 한 종류의 폭행으로 작용해'

translation.en: on the Negro person."
[Brathwaite] In two critical pieces of legislation, the Boggs Act of 1951
and the Eisenhower Narcotics Act, mandatory minimum laws were imposed,
translation.ko: 아이젠하워의 마약법이 시행되며 최소 의무 형량이 도입되었다

translation.en: making it now possible for low-level drug convictions, like cannabis,

translation.ko: - 할 수 있는 게 없다더군요 - 아무것도 못 한대요

translation.en: [Bosworth] Everybody involved on the district court, with the exception of the D.A.,

From a joint.

One joint.

Yeah.

There's so many levels of prejudice even if it's just kind of subconscious,

translation.en: even if it's just systemic as opposed to intentional.
That has definitely created a cycle of disproportionate abuse,

translation.en: [Bosworth] We have financially incentivized incarceration so much,

translation.en: building a system where sheriffs become dependent on high incarceration rates.
translation.ko: 보안관들은 높은 수감률을 바라고 있는 상황이에요

translation.en: The short offenses, the two, three, four, five-year sentences go to local prisons.
Those prisons operate on a per diem.
translation.ko: 그 교도소는 하루 단위로 예산을 받아요

translation.en: They bill the states for every person that they have in their facility per day.
translation.ko: 그날 교도소에 있는 수감자 수에 맞게 예산을 청구하죠

translation.en: Over the past 20 years,
they've expanded those jails in order to bring in more inmates and make more money.
translation.ko: 그 교도소들은 수감자를 늘려서 돈을 더 받으려고 감옥을 키웠어요

translation.en: They then employ more people.
They become, in some parishes, the largest employers in the parish.
translation.ko: 어떤 교도소는 그 지역에서 가장 많은 일자리를 갖고 있죠

translation.en: And their political clout grows accordingly.
When my stepson, who I co-parented,
was a young man, like a lot of young men, he liked to smoke marijuana.
translation.ko: 다른 어린 친구들처럼 마리화나를 즐겨 피웠어요

translation.en: And... he was arrested for it.
That cycling early on into the prison system set a young man,
translation.ko: 그렇게 한 청년이 이른 나이에 교도소 체제에 물들게 되니까

translation.en: who, at one time, had wanted to be a massage therapist,
translation.ko: 한때 안마 치료사가 되고 싶다고 했고

translation.en: who wanted to be a healer, onto a path that said,
translation.ko: 사람을 치료하고 싶다고 했던 그 아이가 이런 생각에 갇혔어요

translation.en: "All you can do is cycle in and out of prison.
All you can do is be a drug seller."
It was almost like there was a conspiracy to say
translation.ko: 마치 그 좁은 선택지 안에서 살아갈 수밖에 없다고 말하는

translation.en: that you can only live within this very narrow confines.
translation.ko: 마치 그 좁은 선택지 안에서 살아갈 수밖에 없다고 말하는 어떤 음모가 있는 것만 같았죠

translation.en: After he got a record, he could not really get any kind of job worth anything.

translation.en: He continued sort of working in an underground economy.

translation.en: He was shot in April of 2005.

translation.ko: 마약 관련 폭력 사건에 휘말려 살해당했어요

translation.en: I'm aware that I do this work standing in the blood... of my child.
translation.ko: 저는 내 아이의 피 위에 서서 이 일을 하고 있어요

translation.en: But I also know that my story is not unique.
translation.ko: 하지만 내 이야기는 전혀 특별한 게 아니에요

translation.en: I know that this is a story of men I love,

translation.ko: 나와 교감하는 공동체 사람들이 모두 겪는 이야기예요

translation.en: I am of them, and they are of me.
I've watched millions and millions of people just...
translation.ko: 저는 정말 수없이 많은 사람들을 봐왔어요

translation.en: thrown away, thrown into a prison system, said that you don't count,
translation.ko: 교도소 안에 내던져진 그들은 자기 삶이 전혀 소중하지 않다는

translation.en: said that you don't matter.
To me, every life has value.
translation.ko: 하지만 제 눈에는 모든 생명이 소중해 보여요

translation.en: [man] Young black men are the most incarcerated people in the history of the world.
translation.ko: 세계의 역대 교도소 수감자를 보면 어린 흑인 남성이 가장 많아요

translation.en: Prisons are like dumping grounds for people who society regards as garbage.
translation.ko: 사회의 쓰레기 취급 받는 사람들이 버려지는 곳이 교도소죠

translation.en: As a prosecutor, one of my tasks was prosecuting drug crimes...
translation.ko: 검사 시절 제 임무는 마약 범죄를 기소하는 거였어요

translation.en: including the most frequently prosecuted drug crime, marijuana.
translation.ko: "폴 버틀러 작가, 법대 교수" 그중 가장 흔하게 기소되었던 약은 마리화나죠

translation.en: I went after, like every other prosecutor did,

translation.ko: 마리화나를 사용하고 판매하는 많은 흑인 청년들을 뒤쫓았어요 "조지타운 대학교 법 센터"

translation.en: But here's the problem.
If you go to a criminal court in DC, then, that was in the 1990s,
translation.ko: 1990년대에 워싱턴 DC에 있는 형사 법원에 들어가면

translation.en: and now, you would think that white people don't commit crimes.
translation.ko: 백인들은 범죄를 안 저지른다고 생각하게 돼요

translation.en: White people are about 40% the population of the District of Columbia,
translation.ko: 워싱턴 DC 인구의 40%가 백인으로 이루어져 있는데

translation.en: but they are not present in the criminal court.
translation.ko: 형사 법정에서는 백인을 볼 수 없거든요

translation.en: And it took me too long to realize this, but at the end of the day,
translation.ko: 저는 너무 오래 걸렸지만 결국 깨달았어요

translation.en: I understood I didn't go to Harvard Law School to put black people in prison.
translation.ko: 난 흑인을 감옥에 넣으려고 하버드 로스쿨을 나온 게 아니구나

translation.en: And that was the work that I was doing.
My presence as a black prosecutor was supposed to send a message.
translation.ko: 그런 일을 하는 흑인 검사를 보고 사람들은 이렇게 생각하는 거예요

translation.en: I know you don't see anybody but black people being prosecuted,
young black men like me.
But it's all good.
Everything's cool.
Go to sleep.
I can imagine that it sucks to be sitting in prison for a weed charge
translation.ko: 대마초 때문에 감옥에 갇히면 정말 기분이 안 좋을 것 같아요

translation.en: and seeing people make so much money off of it.
translation.ko: 더군다나 내가 갇히면 어떤 사람들은 돈을 벌잖아요

translation.en: I'd be pissed. I'm pissed for them.
I got five years, because it was a mandatory minimum.
translation.ko: 전 5년을 받았는데 그게 최소 의무 형량이었거든요

translation.en: The judge couldn't go under that.
Now I'm a two-time felon. I get one more, I'm gone for 25 years.
translation.ko: 지금 전 전과 2범인데 한 번 더 잡히면 25년 받아요

translation.en: You have, you know, laws changing state by state,
but guys like me still can't participate
translation.ko: 저 같은 사람들은 조용히 지내야 하죠

translation.en: because it's still federally illegal to be a part of anything.
translation.ko: 연방법에 걸리기 때문에 범죄 활동을 하면 안 되거든요

translation.en: When you get into a legal or regulated cannabis industry,
you have a crazy background check.
I was fortunate enough to talk my way out of every situation I've ever had
translation.ko: 저는 운이 좋아서 여러 상황에 처했는데도

translation.en: and not go to jail. You know what I'm saying?
That allowed me to get up the ladder,
but a lot of cats in the street that have the knowledge of the herb
and how to move the herb, how to grow it, they're not allowed to be in this game.

CEOs.

Our story ends where a lot of it begins,
